It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to pioneer life in other areas, but prove impossible for you to answer, so there is sufficient space to mark blank spaces. The object of the questionnaire is to give detailed or descriptive particular answers, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

First Questionnaire

Western Canadian Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat? is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, we would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ).

Second Questionnaire

Western Canadian Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Of those are listed below, please mark the ones you will be willing to answer:

- All Questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Registration of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A LIST OF QUESTIONS TO THE PERSONS INTERVIEWED ON THE QUESTIONNAIRE

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual has been asked to answer it. It has not been necessary to ask questions which would be applicable to all persons interviewed. The questions have been selected to give details or describe particular events, if they fail to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1924, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than two members of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

OTHER QUESTIONNAIRES

Western Canadian Archives Questionnaire No. 1 entitled "Pioneer Diets: What Did Western Canadians Pioneer Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, we would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here.

Each Canadian Archives questionnaire on other subjects will be prepared at a later date.

Willing to answer:

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life; sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Encouragement of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be returned to the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our province. Please send your completed questionnaires to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.

RULE: Please print all proper names and places names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: C.H.A.R.L.E.S. BAILEY

2. Your address: La Porte

3. Date: October 5, 1903

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)

5. What was your father's name and occupation?

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

Lived and worked in La Porte, Canada from 1870-5, then settled in Saskatchewan.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," etc.)

9. What were your reasons for coming West?

To homestead and farm.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

By correspondence and word of mouth.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

By thought it was OK

12. Did you travel alone or with a party (family, friends etc.)?

Travelled alone

13. What means of transportation did you use?

C.P.R.

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents etc.)

The cabin was very hot

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At Wabato

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Wabato

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

March 8, 1910 - 1910 Fifth Ward

Some streets & 8a. street

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Farmed, fished & cut wood, found labor for lack, I am not sure, thinking my job was dry mills until I had a chance

19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

At least once a month

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Married Josephine E. Bailey on Dec. 22nd 1907

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

A brother settled at Willsboro and a sister at Saskatchewan also a brother at Longview

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stand out in your memory which you would like to record?

People were friendly, the winters very cold, the snows very deep

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How far? By what means of travel?

Primarily I organized Bailey school & R.M. #6 also a director of municipal hospital now a director of Bailey No. 4 Rural school area. We went by horse and buggy.

Owner ranching, better farming and fewer population, probably good crops & timber, very few horses & cattle.
